unit_learning_outcomes.description: Describe and apply theories and models of change management and organisational development
Demonstrate an understanding of the considerations required when designing, administering, and reporting surveys in an organisational setting, including ethical issues.
Apply a basic level of competence in diagnosing, planning, implementing, and evaluating an organisational change/development intervention
Identify and compare evidence-based individual, group, and organisational-wide approaches to organisational change/development interventions
Demonstrate a basic level of interpersonal skills that enable effective oral and written communication with organisational clients throughout a change/development process

assessments.description: Students are required to respond to a series of 5 short answer questions of 500 words each, in relation to a hypothetical organisational change scenario.

In this case study analysis of 2500 words, students are required to link culture and culture change theories with organisational development interventions in a real business situation. It highlights the practical and theoretical issues involved in identifying cultural challenges and designing and implementing a culture change intervention.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Intensive attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit is designed to enable students to acquire the knowledge necessary to identify the need for organisational change, establish the principles of organisational change from an organisational psychological perspective, and evaluate the outcomes of organisational change, particularly in terms of the psychological demands on workers. Students will be introduced to survey design and development to meet a range of purposes and will learn about the practical aspects of survey administration.
data.title: Organisational Change and Development
